bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, August 21, 1954

div1.p: Hench tries to locate the cemetery where Lazear and other American soldiers were temporarily buried in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, August 21, 1954
div1.opener:
August 21, 1954
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
You and I have been trying to find out where was the cemetery in which Lazear
and other American soldiers were temporarily buried in 1900 and so on. I
have found a clue that may be helpful. I have discussed with General Truby
and others the old cemetery site which you pointed out to me on one of my
recent visits there and of which I took pictures. General Truby and others
thought it was too far away from Camp Lazear and probably on the wrong side
of the railroad track.

In “A Report of Major General Leonard Wood, U. S. V., Commanding, Department
of Cuba, Havana Cuba, June 30, 1901,” I find several notes regarding the
cemetery. In one report, on page 11, I find notes about the type of caskets
used and in another report on page 21, I find the work of disinterment of
American soldiers was performed between December 1, 1900 and February 24,
1901, and the remains of 102 officers and soldiers and 66 civilians were
carried to New York on Army transports between February 14 and March 9,
1901.

But most important of all, I find, in exhibit Y entitled “Formal Contracts
(paid from Insular Funds) For Lands and Buildings occupied for Military
Purposes, executed by Chief Quartermaster, Department of Cuba, during Fiscal
Year ending June 30, 1901,” the following note: “Major C. B. Baker, C.Q.M.,
Vendee; name of Contractor, Ramon Gonzalez Socorro; date of Contract, April 20,
1901; Nature of Contract, Conveyance, Government Cemetery, Columbia Barracks;
Consideration, $300.00.

I would interpret this as meaning that the land temporarily rented for the
Army cemetery was owned by Ramon Gonzalez Socorro and if we can find a
real estate evidence as to just where in the neighborhood of Camp Columbia
Senor Ramon Gonzalez Socorro had property, we would know where the cemetery was.

I have also tried to find a complete real estate map of the land rented for
Camp Columbia. I found an incomplete map showing the boundaries of a number
of parcels owned by various Cubans giving exact locations and sizes, but
parcel No. 14, which was that of the military cemetery, does not happen to
be indicated on the maps I have.

I wonder if the above information is enough of a clue for you to start
your inquiries. Next time I come I will bring this book and the in-
complete maps, and on my return from Europe I will try to locate a com-
plete Army “property map.”

Incidentally, I think that the book I have was published not in the United
States but in Cuba. It is bound like a Cuban book. At the bottom on
the back of the book is the name Anson Mills, Brigadier General, U. S. A.
and since the format and binding of this book are quite different from
somewhat similar reports of Wood and others published in Washington, I
am almost positive that this was published in Havana. Maybe you could
find a copy of it in some old second-hand book stores in Havana.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
